talk tofu otherwise called bean curd now
what is tofu well the best way to
describe it broadly speaking is it's the
non-dairy version of cheese okay so what
you need to do is instead of using dairy
take soya beans and turn that into soya
milk take the soya milk and heat that up
to kill off the natural enzymes or
denature them then you can add a
coagulant now that could be salt or acid
either way it separates it into curds
and whey and it's those curds there are
the solids and that is tofu if you take
it in its softest silkiest form you have
soft tofu if you take that tofu and
compress it and dry out you end up with
firm tofu both very good but for
different reasons
either way though pretty bland so here
are a few tips to make your tofu great
tip number one quality like with any
ingredient if you want a quality dish
you need quality product so depending on
where the world you are it may be easier
to get hold of tofu but the fresh stuff
is the best especially in places like
Japan where it's made with natural
seawater
it's the magnesium chloride in there
that gives you a very soft and silken
fresh tofu if you're buying something
off the shelf that's been packaged it
tends to be a little bit firmer and it
tends to be made using other process
that are more controlled in the
manufacturing process but as a result
tend to be slightly drier or more
crumbly so wherever possible get the
freshest tofu you can number two if
you're using a firm tofu freeze it and
that'll maybe to get more flavor in the
reason being the structure of tofu is
much like a sponge and it's about 80 to
90 percent water so if you freeze it
that water expands into ice crystals and
pushes the protein strands apart then
when it defrost and thaws
you're left with those holes and kind of
a sponge-like structure that sponge will
absorb flavor as you cook it
number three storing your tofu it's best
to keep it fresh and moist to do that
submerged in plain old tap water in the
fridge that's the best way to keep it
freshest for
yes however we said it was like a sponge
so it absorbs a lot of that water what
you need to do before using it is take
it out damage it between kitchen roll or
a very clean dish cloth and just put a
small weight on top that will draw out a
lot of the moisture you need to somehow
that water to come out of the sponge
before you start cooking it otherwise
there's no room for the flavors to go in
number four use a marinade on your tofu
so having dried it cut it into whatever
size pieces you want by increasing the
surface area you can get more flavor in
and then for fear of repeat myself tofu
has a lot of water in it and oil and
water don't mix so if you have a
marinade that's oil-based it's simply
not going to go into the tofu it's
simply going to run off instead use
marinades that are water-based stocks
soy alcohol anything like that lemon
juice also really good you can add
flavors and herbs to it but that's the
best marinade so cut it up to increase
the surface area and then marinate in a
water-based Marigny
number five texture is awesome
so although tofu can be used in so many
different things if you are frying it
just one of many methods then what
you're best off doing is coating your
little cubes of tofu in cornflour the
cool flour could be heavily seasoned or
spiced with drying spices and what that
does is you fry it is it locks in the
moisture but crisps up the outside it
will go golden brown and you get a
perfect tofu that's well seasoned and
well favored if you understand what tofu
is and its structure then you can think
about how to make it work in a recipe
